awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Acquisition of a Tomographic Particle Image Velocimetry System for Fluid-Structure Interaction Investigation of Active Blowing on Deformable Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Active blowing methods have shown tremendous improvements in delay separation, lift enhancement and noise reduction over the years, however a major roadblock associated with high mass flow requirements has restricted their use on aircraft platforms. One potential method to resolve this issue is to synthesize and utilize two seemingly unique active flow control methods, a deformable flap providing a continuous wing contour and active upper-surface blowing, to develop a more efficient active flow control system that can enhance aircraft performance and control. The primary aim of this project is to investigate and determine the key factors governing the performance of active blowing on deformable surfaces. The project will also support the integration of research with graduate and undergraduate education and it will attract, educate and help retain a diverse pool of scientists/engineers including underrepresented minorities from partner institutions.

The goal of this project is to conduct an experimental flow-structure interaction investigation to impact our understanding of the key parameters that effect the formation and development of coherent structures near deformable wing flap with upper-surface trailing-edge blowing. Computational studies are scarce due to the high complexity of the equations that govern the flow. Experimental results focused on the coherent structures of active blowing on deformable surfaces are also sparse; therefore, the current project will produce a detailed experimental database for unsteady flow-structure interaction for this application in a low-speed wind tunnel using a state-of-the-art tomographic particle image velocimetry system to obtain velocities. These results can be used to develop a physical understanding of the problem and to improve computational tools. The project will i) determine the properties (varying slot geometry on the deformable flap, slot-height, blowing intensity and Reynolds number) that govern the performance of active blowing on deformable flaps and ii) identify and quantify the effects of geometry, frequency of actuation and blowing intensity on the formation and development on coherent structures. This project is jointly funded by the Fluid Dynamics and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA IN HUNTSVILLE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This proposal requested support for the acquisition of equipment and software to upgrade an existing 2D Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) to a Tomographic PIV (Tomo-PIV) system. The proposed system provided the ability to carry out volumentric velocimetry measurements, which is a key facilitator for investigating and understanding 3D unsteady turbulent flows. It created a unique opportunity to develop transformative research and achieve long-term research goal, which is to establish a framework that associates wing's active surface deformation and wall-blowing intensity with the near-wall coherent structures to design active flow control (AFC) systems that manipulate flow structures for efficient boundary-layer control. Data collected with the system provided insight into the physics of 3D complex and turbulent flow structures. The advanced Tomo-PIV system enabled the study of fundamental advances in fluid dynamics and the development of transformational active flow control technologies. The state-of-the-art Tomo-PIV system provided the opportunity to collect a high-quality data sets that can improve the understanding of 3D flow structure during active blowing on moving surfaces, while developing a novel measurement technique for AFC applications. Data collected from the proposed project helped the PI to develop more accurate models to characterize turbulence and boundary layer separation. 

The proposed system helped the PI to produce highly transformational results and develop research that will advance in science, engineering and design of next-generation AFC systems with important applications, such as the improvement of: i) aircraft aerodynamic performance by targeting more environmentally friendly air transport systems; ii) helicopter blade design performance (noise reduction); iii) actuators performance for boundary-layer ingesting engine's inlet;  and  iv) wind turbine performance. The PIV system attracted, educated and helped retain a diverse pool of scientists/engineers including underrepresented minorities from partner institutions. In addition, it supported the integration of research with graduate and undergraduate education. Undergraduate research assistants were recruited to assist on the projects to be enabled and graduate students that chose their thesis/dissertation on related topics were trained to use the system for research. Utilization of the system produced critical knowledge while accelerating transformative research leading to next generation of aircraft with enhanced capabilities. 


Last Modified: 02/03/2023
Modified by: Konstantinos Kanistras
